item.title: Extension
item.description:
Australian residents pay tax using the percentages below. IF another wealthy business-person lives in Australia and earns $92,578 before tax, what is their after tax income? Show all working.

Working out:

The formula to calculate tax payable for the business-person is , but this can also be rewritten like this:

Which looks much cleaner
Answer:
The business-person's after tax income is $72,023.15

item.title: A
item.description:
The number of Muslims is the same as the number of people who are undernourished.
Required clues:
B: There are three times as many people who do not have a college education, as there are Christians
C: There are 6 Buddhists.
O: The ratio of Christians to Buddhists is 5.5:1
Q: A person is as likely to have a college education as they are to have HIV or to be dying of starvation.
H: Half of the people are hungry most or all of the time
K: 30% of people have enough to eat. Half of the people who have enough to eat are overweight and half are not
Working out:
This question is a tricky one. There are no questions directly relating to undernourishment, but we can use the process of elimination in the table for the answers. To figure out the number of people who are undernourished, we can use this formula:

So the full calculation looks like this:

Answer to clue:
There are 19 people who are undernourished, and 19 muslims.

Clues needed to answer this question:

O: The ratio of christians to Buddhists is 5.5:1
Steps taken:


The answer to this question is: There are 99 people who do not have a college education

are Europeans.

Working out:
We need to make the denominator of the fraction 100, to represent the number of people. We can do this by multiplying each part of the fraction by four (Which is )

item.title: If the world were a village of 100 people
item.description:
This document is formatted as shown below:
Name of item: value (How it was worked out, either a short sentence or a clickable link to a clue)

Population distribution:
Asia: 59 (E)
Africa: 15 (D)
Europe: 12 (I)
Americas: 14 (F)
Gender
Male: 48 (P)
Female: 52 (P)
Age
Adult: 70 (P)
Children: 30 (P)
Skin colour
White: 30 (X)
Non-white: 70 (X)

Russian: 6 (J)
Hindi: 8 (U)
Spanish: 6 (W)
English: 9 (S)
Chinese: 17 (R)
Arabic: 4 (U)
Other: 50 (Found by subtracting the sum of all languages from 100)

Christian: 33 (O)
Muslim: 19 (A)
Buddhist: 6 (C)
Hindu: 13 (G)
Belief in spirits: 5 (Found by subtracting sum of all religions from 100)
Other/Atheist: 24 (L)

Undernourished and dying of starvation: 1 (Q)
Undernourished: 19 (Found by subtracting the sum of all values in this section from 100)
Hungry most or all of the time: 50 (H)
Have enough to eat but not overweight: 15 (K)
3Have enough to eat and are overweight: 15 (K)

Clean water
Access to clean water: 83 (Found from subtracting the amount of people without clean water from 100)
No access to clean water: 17 (N)
Clean air
Access to clean air: 68 (M)
No access to clean air: 68 (M)
Computers
Access to computers: 7 (Found from subtracting the number of people without computers from 100)
No access to computers: 93 (T)
Electricity
Access to electricity: 76 (L)
No access to electricity: (L)
Literacy
Can read: 86 (Found by subtracting the number of people who can't read from 100)
Can't read: 14 (V)
Education
College education: 1 (Found by subtracting the number of people with a college education from 100)
No college education: 99 (B)
HIV
Not infected by HIV: 99 (Found by subtracting the number of people with HIV from 100)
Infected by HIV: 1 (Q)
item.guid: Part A/If the world were a village of 100 people.md

item.title: J
item.description:
There are the same number of people who speak Spanish and Russian.
Required clues:
C: There are 6 Buddhists
W: The same number of people that are Buddhists, speak Spanish.

Answer to clue:
There are 6 people who speak spanish and 6 people who speak russian.

item.title: K
item.description:
30% of people have enough to eat. Half of the people who have enough to eat are overweight and half are not.
Required clues:
None
Working out:

Answer to clue:
30 people have enough to eat. Of those people, 15 are overweight and 15 are not.

item.title: L
item.description:
76% of people have electricity. The number of people without electricity is the same as the number of people in the Atheist/Other religion category

Answer to this clue:
The number of people with electricity is 76. The number of people without it is 24. The number of people in the Atheist/Other religion category is 24.

item.title: M
item.description:

Required clues:
None
Working out:

Answer to question:
There are 68 people with clean air and 32 people without clean air

Working out:

are children and 52% are female

item.title: Part B
item.description:
Based on recent trends, it is suggested that by 2030 the richest 1% of the global population will own two-thirds of the global wealth. Bob is a wealthy businessman within the village who belongs in the richest 1%.
Bob's wealth has come from selling furniture, with a business model that looks like this:

Furniture is bought by the businessman at cost price
The businessman adds profit, which help to cover his costs
Furniture is bought by the customer for the selling price


Bob has three other business partners who work with him - Savvy Sally, Creative Chris, and Profit Pete. Based on their experience Bob, Sally, Chris, and Pete share the profit in the ratio . If the furniture company earns $1,052,112 in a year, how much will each partner receive?
Working out:

Answer:
All of these answers have been rounded to two decimal places
Bob gets $478,323.73
Sally gets $382,586.18
Chris gets $95,646.55
Pete gets $95,646.55

The wealthy businessman is great at business, but not so good with the accounting.
It is coming up to the ned of the financial year (tax time), so he needs to provide evidence of his profit and some information that has gone missing.
Help the businessman to complete his books using your understanding of percentages, showing all working:
All answers that I wrote (Weren't already filled in), are in Bold italics

Bowl working out:

Blanket working out:

Lamp working out:

item.title: Conclusion
item.description:
Summarise what you found in the results:
In these results I found the distribution in percentages of religion, race, access to resources, and languages spoken throughout the world. I also found out how businesses can buy and sell products at certain prices to increase profit.
Were there any specific things that you found interesting or that surprised you
The requirement of some questions to use deduction/process of elimination surprised me as I thought I would be able to work all clues out just with other clues. It also surprised me in the results that only 1 person in this village had a degree, as I thought there would be more people than that.
How do you think the accuracy of the investigation could be improved
The accuracy of the overall investigation could be improved by giving the data a larger sample size as a larger sample size would better reflect what happens in the real world. This is because taking data from a larger group of people decreases the chance for outliers to skew the results.
Were there any limitations to the investigation that could affect the accuracy of your answers/findings?
There was a limitation of some facts not being accurate to real world data, which could affect the accuracy of some answers as it would cause some people to doubt themselves and change the answer that was correct in the first place.

item.title: index
item.description:
What does the investigation aim to find out/solve?
This investigation aims to find out facts about the real world in percentages, such as race, language, religion, and access to certain resources. It also aims to find out how much tax people pay in Australia, aims to solve how much money things should sell for relative to their cost price.
Why are we investigation these mathematical and cultural topics in particular?
We are investigation these specific mathematical and cultural topics because percentages are used in a lot of things in life, and are one of the most useful things in maths. The real world data aspect of this investigation could help us understand the world we live in more.

For part A, click here
For part B, click here
For the extension, click here
